Posts.Content: First time on forum, just wanted to meet up with others in the same boat, share my initial outcome from surgery and see what you folks think. Diagnosed June, 2015, 2 of 12 cores showed cancer, 5% and 10%, Gleason 9 (4+5), had surgery in August, Seminal vesicles impacted, and one lymph node of 24 had a VERY small number of TINY, TINY (doc's words) micro cells. Initial PSA was 10.9. Got my first PSA today post-surgery, came back at <.019 - which to me (as a Gleason 9) makes me very encouraged, and tells me it was caught early. I know I'll be monitored closely for the rest of my life, but am I on track with that thinking? Thanks, Ken
Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Content: BTW, because of the Gleason 9 AND extremely small impact on only one lymph node of 24 - he made me get the PSA after only two months, not three.
Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Diagnosed June, 2015, 2 of 12 cores showed cancer, 5% and 10%, Gleason 9 (4+5), had surgery in August, Seminal vesicles impacted, and one lymph node of 24 had a VERY small number of TINY, TINY (doc's words) micro cells. Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Content: Got my consult Friday with the surgeon about the PSA result, declared cancer free! As some have mentioned, I have to be vigilant, get PSA every three months for a while, but what a great feeling to know that, as of now, it's gone. Thanks for all the input and support!

Posts.Content: Got my consult Friday with the surgeon about the PSA result, declared cancer free! As some have mentioned, I have to be vigilant, get PSA every three months for a while, but what a great feeling to know that, as of now, it's gone. Thanks for all the input and support!
